content:
Establishment of the Independent Commission on Intelligence about Iraq in the legislative branch. Duties of the Commission. The Independent Commission on Intelligence about Iraq in the legislative branch is tasked with evaluating executive branch efforts to collect intelligence on Iraq's threats, including nuclear weapons, chemical and biological weapons, and support for terrorist organizations. They also assess the credibility of intelligence, interpret conclusions, and review public representations made by executive branch officials. The Independent Commission on Intelligence about Iraq in the legislative branch evaluates collaborative arrangements for collecting and interpreting threats, reviews restrictions on intelligence collection imposed by Congress, and examines previous investigations to report findings to Congress and the President. The Independent Commission on Intelligence about Iraq will report its findings and recommendations to Congress and the President to enhance the accuracy of intelligence. The composition of the commission is outlined in Section 3. The Commission consists of 10 members appointed by various leaders, with specific roles assigned to each member. The Commission consists of 10 members appointed by various leaders, with specific roles assigned to each member. Nongovernmental appointees must not be government officials. Members should be prominent US citizens with expertise in various fields. All members must be appointed within 45 days of the Act's enactment, and the Commission should start operations promptly. The Commission consists of 10 members appointed by various leaders, with specific roles assigned to each member. Nongovernmental appointees must not be government officials. Members should be prominent US citizens with expertise in various fields. All members must be appointed within 45 days of the Act's enactment, and the Commission should start operations promptly. The Commission shall meet upon the call of the chairman or a majority of its members, with six members constituting a quorum. Vacancies will not affect the Commission's powers and will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Each member must submit a financial disclosure report as per the Ethics in Government Act of 1978. The Commission, consisting of 10 members appointed by various leaders, has specific roles assigned to each member. Nongovernmental appointees must not be government officials. Members should be prominent US citizens with expertise in various fields. All members must be appointed within 45 days of the Act's enactment, and the Commission should start operations promptly. The Commission shall meet upon the call of the chairman or a majority of its members, with six members constituting a quorum. Vacancies will not affect the Commission's powers and will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Each member must submit a financial disclosure report as per the Ethics in Government Act of 1978. The Commission, or any subcommittee or member, may hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, and issue subpoenas to witnesses and documents as needed for carrying out its duties. Subpoenas under this subsection can only be issued by agreement of the chairman and vice chairman or by an affirmative vote of 6 Commission members. Subpoenas may be signed by the chairman or a designated member and served by a designated person. Enforcement measures apply in cases of contumacy. In cases of contumacy or failure to obey a subpoena, the United States district court may issue an order requiring the person to testify or produce evidence. Failure to comply may result in contempt of court. The Commission may certify witness failures to the US attorney for grand jury action. The Commission can examine actions and representations under its duties. The Commission has the authority to examine actions and representations of current and prior Administrations. It can enter into contracts and obtain information from federal agencies to fulfill its duties under the Act. The Commission can request information from federal agencies and receive administrative support from the General Services Administration for its functions. Information handling must comply with relevant laws and regulations. The Commission may receive assistance, services, funds, and support from US departments and agencies as authorized by law. It can also accept gifts, use postal services like other government entities. SEC. 5. NONAPPLICABILITY OF FEDERAL ADVISORY COMMITTEE ACT. The Commission is exempt from the Federal Advisory Committee Act. It will hold public meetings, release public reports, and conduct hearings while protecting sensitive information. SEC. 6. STAFF OF COMMISSION. The chairman, with the vice chairman's consultation, can appoint a staff director and necessary personnel without following certain federal employment regulations. The pay cannot exceed that of a level V Executive Schedule position. The Commission can appoint a staff director and personnel as federal employees under specific regulations. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement and retain their regular employment rights. The Commission can also procure consultant services at specified rates. The Commission can appoint a staff director and personnel as federal employees under specific regulations, with rates not exceeding those of a person at level IV of the Executive Schedule. SEC. 7. COMPENSATION AND TRAVEL EXPENSES. Members of the Commission may receive compensation at a daily rate equivalent to level IV of the Executive Schedule. They are also entitled to travel expenses while performing Commission duties. SEC. 8. SECURITY CLEARANCES FOR COMMISSION MEMBERS AND STAFF. Federal agencies must provide security clearances to Commission members and staff. Access to classified information requires the appropriate security clearance. The Commission can submit interim and final reports to Congress and the President with findings, conclusions, and recommendations. Reports must be in unclassified form but may include a classified annex. If deemed in the public interest, certain classified information may be made available to the public. The Commission can recommend making certain information public, and the congressional intelligence committees will consider the recommendation following specific procedures for declassifying information. The term "congressional intelligence committees" refers to the Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence of the House of Representatives and the Select Committee on Intelligence of the Senate. SEC. 10. TERMINATION.

The Commission and its authorities will end 60 days after submitting the final report. During this period, the Commission can wrap up its activities, testify before Congress, and share the final report.

SEC. 11. FUNDING.

Up to $5,000,000 is authorized for the Commission's activities under this Act. The funds will be available until the Commission terminates.
